1. Outright purchase of an existing VHF commercial
station* This is bound to be exceedingly and
perhaps prohibitorily expensive* This could
probably be accomplished only in New York or Los
Angeles, where there are 7 YJIF stations.
2. Transfer of an existing commercial VHF channel
to educational use through rule-making proceedings
before the FCC« The difficulties of this course
of action are obvious bec«.u^e of the inevitable
direct oonflict with existing interests.
3. The addition of VHF channels by way of relocation
or "drop-in" as in Detroit and Rochester. This
is by far the simplest method, but such
opportunities are bound to be infrequent.
4. Time-sharing arrangements on existing VHF
channels that are presently utilized commercially.
This would require FCC action modifying licenses
of commercial stations so as to make available time
on channels for part time educational licensees.
Under these circumstances, it is our recommendation that
the JCKT should now seek a general investigative proceeding
before the FCC under Section 1.10 of the Commission’s Rules.
This rule provides that:
Section 1.10 Proceedings before the Commission. The
Commission may on its own motion or petition of
any Interested party bold such proceedings as it
n0c0fi«*ry from time to time in connection
with the investigation of any matter which it has
power to investigate under the law, or for the
purpose of obtaining information necessary or
helpful in the determination of its policies, the
carrying out of its duties, or the formulation or
amendment of its rules and regulations. For such
purpose it may subpena witnesses and require the
production of evidence. Procedures to be followed
by the Commission shall, unless specifically
prescribed in this part, be such as in the opinion
of the Commission will best serve the purposes of
such proceeding.
